title: Child Soldiers
author: Dhruv Agrawal
text:
We all have met children, many young and charming faces who have dreams, aspirations, and curiosity. Many of us have family and friends under 15. Now, imagine these small, innocent children, girls and boys, pick up a gun or a bomb, inhale some marijuana, and walk into a town and shoot, rape, and destroy other children their age. This may all seem like a nightmare but for many countries it is a reality. Children as young as 8 years of age are enlisted to battle in a war they did not start, develop, or understand. Grievingly, these children are sent to be suicide bombers and mere tools for their oppressive, tyrannical governments to use for power gain. The conditions these children are put in are amazingly depressing. They are mercilessly put into battle with no support, but merely pawns sent to die with no proper memories or experiences.

Using children as soldiers has been a practice of our species for centuries. The only difference between our world right now and the Ottoman Turkish Empire in the Sultans Personal Elite Corps is that now our child soldiers have experienced harsher conditions and have been using much more painful tools of destruction. There are many reasons why the number of child soldiers has recently increased. It is because the tools have gotten lighter, easier to handle and assemble, children are easier to take care of, they do not need to be paid, are easier to capture, and can be easily convinced. So now you have this malleable war machine known as a child soldier. Many nations have utilized child soldiers. Child soldiers were used in the American Civil War for during battle, used by Russia and Germany during World War 2, China used them against Burma in 1944, Uganda have children in their Lords Resistance Army, Somalia continues to raid school to get children for battl. Many other countries throughout Europe, Asia, Africa, and South America can be put within this category. More recently, ISIL has been recruiting children as young as 10 in their forces.

There is much we can do about resolving the global issue of child soldiers. To start, we can donate to UNICEF, UNHCR (United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees), and HRW (Human Rights Watch). The UN also passed Resolution 1261 declaring what the conditions must be for a child to be a child soldier and how the world must bring a cease in child soldiers because it is in direct violation of international law. Since then, the UN and several other agencies have been pulling children out of wars. Despite their efforts, many more thousand remain in the battlefields waiting to be rescued. To allow for more efficient freedom for the children, I would suggest primarily deciding whether the government is tyrannical and oppressive and whether it is globally powerful or weak. Then, the UN should decide whether the government is in direct violation of humanitarian rights, in which R2P can be applied. Finally, based on the responses from the first two questions, the UN either invades the country with more than enough forces to ensure victory and put in place a new and better government or attempts to solve the problem diplomatically, always having the second option of invasion.
